title: Innovations
text: My work involves developing open-source tools, cloud applications, and browser extensions to streamline geospatial workflows for researchers and data scientists.

title: Innovations
text:
üåç Earth Engine Apps




GeoMapper


Interactive geospatial mapping dashboard built with R Shiny.


 App





Spectral Reflectance Curve


Advanced tool for analyzing spectral signatures across multiple bands for land cover characterization.


 App  GitHub





Phenology Signature


Automating crop classification using multi-temporal phenological patterns and signature analysis.


 App  GitHub





Flood Susceptibility


Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP) implementation for rigorous regional flood vulnerability mapping.


 App  GitHub





Odisha Flood Map


Real-time monitoring and visualization of flood extent using SAR and multi-spectral satellite imagery.


 App  GitHub

title: Innovations
text:
üì¶ Python Packages




geeadvance


A Python package for functional programming utilities to streamline Earth Engine API workflows.


 PyPI  GitHub





deepgee


Bridge GEE datasets with Deep Learning models for automated satellite imagery classification.


 PyPI  GitHub





geeassist


Small Python library to interact with LLMs for generating and debugging GEE code snippets.


 PyPI  GitHub

title: Innovations
text:
üìö R Library




rpygee


An R wrapper providing a seamless interface to run Google Earth Engine via the Python API.


 Docs  GitHub

title: Innovations
text:

GEE AI Assistant


Chrome extension that integrates Gemini AI directly into the GEE Code Editor for rapid scripts.


 Store  GitHub





Quick Screenshot


Browser tool for high-resolution geospatial map capture, optimized for academic publication.


 Store

title: Basics of Google Earth Engine & LULC Classification
text:
Topic: Basics of Google Earth Engine & LULC Classification
Date: September 13, 2025
Time: 7:00 PM ‚Äì 9:00 PM
Host: Maharaja Sriram Chandra Bhanja Deo University
Mode: Virtual (Google Meet)

title: Basics of Google Earth Engine & LULC Classification
text:
Event Overview
This session focused on introducing Google Earth Engine (GEE) to students and researchers. Key topics covered included:

Introduction to GEE Code Editor and Interface.
Basics of remote sensing data acquisition.
Workflow for Land Use Land Cover (LULC) Classification.
Hands-on demonstration using satellite imagery.

The workshop aimed to equip participants with the essential skills to start their journey in cloud-based geospatial analysis.

title: Basics of Google Earth Engine
text:
Topic: Basics of Google Earth Engine
Trainer: Pulakesh Pradhan
Mode: Virtual (Online)
Host: Centurion University, Bhubaneswar

Saturday, Feb 21, 2026

This intensive session is designed for PG students to build a strong foundation in Google Earth Engine for geospatial analysis.

title: Publications
text:
üìö Book Chapters



Application of analytic hierarchy process for mapping flood vulnerability in Odisha using Google Earth Engine







Pradhan, P., Bajpai, R., & Patra, S. (2025)


In Google Earth Engine and Artificial Intelligence for Earth Observation, Elsevier


This research utilizes the Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP) within the Google Earth Engine environment to map flood vulnerability in Odisha, India. By integrating various geomorphological and climatic parameters, the study produces high-resolution vulnerability maps to assist in disaster management and mitigation strategies.


  Download    DOI 






Agricultural drought monitoring using Google Earth Engine: a study of Paschim Medinipur district, West Bengal







Pradhan, P., & Patra, S. (2024)


In Modern Cartography Series, Elsevier


This study presents a remote sensing-based approach to monitoring agricultural drought in the Paschim Medinipur district. Using long-term satellite data and vegetation indices processed on the cloud, we analyze spatiotemporal drought patterns and their impact on local agriculture.


  Download    DOI

title: Publications
text:
üé§ Presentations


Drought Monitoring with GEE AI Assistant powered by Gemini API







Pradhan, P. (2024)


GDG for Earth Engine Nairobi (Virtual)


A demonstration of integrating Large Language Models (LLMs) with geospatial platforms. This workshop showcases how a Gemini-powered AI assistant can streamline complex GEE coding tasks for drought monitoring, making cloud-based remote sensing more accessible to researchers.


  Download    DOI

title: Publications
text:

Near Real-Time Air Quality Trend Monitoring in Odisha Using Multi-Sensor Satellite Images





Unable to display PDF. Download here.





Pradhan, P., & Bajpai, R. (2023)


Odisha Research Conclave (ORC-2023)


This poster presentation demonstrates a multi-sensor satellite approach for monitoring air quality trends in Odisha. Using a combination of Sentinel-5P and MODIS data, the research provides a near real-time assessment of pollutants to support environmental policy and public health awareness.


  Download PDF    Details

title: Cloud GIS Beyond Google Earth Engine: Why Open Source Matters
text:
In the modern geospatial landscape, Google Earth Engine (GEE) stands as a colossus. Its ability to process petabytes of satellite imagery in seconds has not just revolutionized remote sensing; it has fundamentally altered how we think about planetary-scale analysis. For many students and researchers, ‚ÄúRemote Sensing‚Äù has become synonymous with ‚Äútyping JavaScript into the GEE Code Editor.‚Äù
However, this convenience comes with a hidden cost. As powerful as GEE is, it remains a proprietary tool owned by a tech giant. This introduces a critical vulnerability: the risk of the ‚ÄúWalled Garden.‚Äù

title: Cloud GIS Beyond Google Earth Engine: Why Open Source Matters
section: ‚ö†Ô∏è The Concern: Google‚Äôs Proprietary Tool & Paywall Risk
text:
‚ö†Ô∏è The Concern: Google‚Äôs Proprietary Tool & Paywall Risk
The concern is simple: Google Earth Engine is a proprietary product. Unlike open-source software, its future is entirely dictated by corporate strategy, not community consensus.

The ‚ÄúPaywall Risk‚Äù
History is littered with Google products that started free and later became paid or were discontinued (Google Reader, the shift in Google Maps API pricing, Google Photos storage limits). While GEE is free for research now, there is no guarantee it will remain so forever. A sudden shift to a paywall model could leave researchers and students stranded, with their code locked behind a subscription they cannot afford.


The ‚ÄúWalled Garden‚Äù Problem
When you build your entire workflow in GEE, you are building inside a rented house. * Vendor Lock-in: Your code (GEE JavaScript) is not easily portable. You cannot simply run a GEE script on your local machine or another cloud provider without a complete rewrite. * Black Box Algorithms: While we trust Google‚Äôs implementations, the underlying code for many algorithms is not visible. Science demands transparency, and ‚Äútrust us‚Äù is not a scientific standard.



Vendor Lock-in: Relying solely on proprietary platforms risks hitting invisible walls‚Äîwhether they be quotas, costs, or terms of service.








WarningKey Risks of Sole Reliance on GEE




Sustainability: If Google changes the Terms of Service, your project could die overnight.
Reproducibility: If a specific GEE algorithm changes under the hood, your results might change without you knowing why.
Cost: Commercial use is already paid; academic use is subsidized by Google‚Äôs goodwill.

title: Cloud GIS Beyond Google Earth Engine: Why Open Source Matters
text:
üöÄ We Cannot Ignore Massive Potential
Having said that, we cannot just ignore GEE‚Äôs massive potential. It solves the Data Gravity problem‚Äîinstead of downloading petabytes of data to your computer, you send your code to the data.
For large-scale, server-based analysis, GEE is unrivaled: * Global Scale: Computing Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI) for the entire planet over 20 years takes minutes in GEE, but would take months on a local workstation. * Instant Access: The multi-petabyte catalog of Landsat, Sentinel, and MODIS data is instantly available without downloading a single file.
Startups and researchers leverage this for rapid prototyping and global monitoring systems that would otherwise be impossible. To ignore GEE is to ignore a superpower.

title: Cloud GIS Beyond Google Earth Engine: Why Open Source Matters
text:
‚öñÔ∏è Balancing is the Smartest Way
So, what is the solution? It is not to abandon GEE, but to balance it. We must give more focus to Open Source Technology.
The smartest geospatial workflow is a Hybrid Approach: 1. Use GEE for what it does best (Heavy Lifting). 2. Use Open Source (Python/R) for what it does best (Analysis, Statistics, Visualization, and Freedom).



The Sustainable Pipeline: Leverage the cloud for what it does best (heavy lifting) and local tools for what they do best (precision analysis).



The Hybrid Workflow in Practice








Stage
Tool
Action




1. Ingestion & Pre-processing
Google Earth Engine
Filter collections, cloud masking, temporal compositing (e.g., median annual composites).


2. Export
GEE to Drive/Cloud
Export only the results (the processed bands or indices) as manageable GeoTIFFs or CSVs.


3. Analysis & Modeling
Python / R
Perform deep statistical analysis, machine learning (Scikit-Learn, PyTorch), or complex geostatistics.


4. Visualization
Python (Matplotlib) / R (ggplot2)
Create publication-quality maps and charts that you fully own and control.

title: Cloud GIS Beyond Google Earth Engine: Why Open Source Matters
section: üêç Importance of Open Source Technology: Python and R
text:
üêç Importance of Open Source Technology: Python and R
Open source technologies are the bedrock of scientific reproducibility. When you write code in Python or R, you use libraries built by the community, for the community. You own the stack.



Open Ecosystems: Python and R provide an infinite playground for innovation, free from corporate constraints.



Why Focus on Open Source?

Transparency: You can inspect the code of every library you use (pandas, sf). You know exactly what the math is doing.
Portability: Python code runs on your laptop, on AWS, on Azure, or on a supercomputer. You are not tied to Google.
Community: The geospatial community in Python and R is vibrant and innovative.

Python: The powerhouse of modern data science. Libraries like geopandas, rasterio, xarray, and the Pangeo ecosystem allow for scalable analyses that rival GEE but on open infrastructure.
R: The gold standard for statistics. Packages like sf, terra, and tmap make spatial analysis intuitive and statistically rigorous.








TipThe Future is Open



By mastering Python and R, you future-proof your career. Tools may come and go (remember ArcView 3?), but the concepts and the open-source languages remain relevant for decades.

title: Cloud GIS Beyond Google Earth Engine: Why Open Source Matters
text:
Conclusion
The concern regarding Google Earth Engine‚Äôs proprietary nature is valid. The risk of paywalls and vendor lock-in is real. However, its computational power is undeniably transformative.
The key is Balance. Do not let GEE become a ‚Äúcrutch‚Äù that limits your understanding of underlying geospatial concepts. Instead, treat it as one powerful tool in a larger toolbox. Prioritize learning open-source technologies like Python and R. They offer the freedom, flexibility, and transparency that true scientific inquiry demands.
Use the Cloud for scale, but keep your feet on the Open Source ground.

title: Cloud GIS Beyond Google Earth Engine: Why Open Source Matters
text:
References

Gorelick, N., et al.¬†(2017). ‚ÄúGoogle Earth Engine: Planetary-scale geospatial analysis for everyone.‚Äù Remote Sensing of Environment.
Pangeo Project. (2025). ‚ÄúA community platform for Big Data geoscience.‚Äù pangeo.io
Open Source Geospatial Foundation (OSGeo). ‚ÄúEmpowering everyone with open source geospatial.‚Äù osgeo.org

title: Why in Cloud GIS Google Earth Engien is the only option left?
text:
Why Cloud GIS?
The Cloud GIS is the new paradigm in GIS. It is the new way of doing GIS. It is the new way of doing GIS. It is the new way of doing GIS. It is the new way of doing GIS. It is the new way of doing GIS.
With the advancement of the Google Earth Engine this concept has become more popular.

title: Journals
text:
Prioritizing No-Fee Publishing
To support researchers with limited funding, this list prioritizes journals that offer a ‚ÄúSubscription‚Äù or ‚ÄúHybrid‚Äù model. In this model, authors do NOT pay publication fees (Article Processing Charges - APCs).

  Find Journals with Manuscript Matcher

title: Journals
text:
Publisher Submission Guide: Avoiding Fees
Most top-tier journals are Hybrid, meaning they offer both a Subscription (Free for authors) and an Open Access (Paid) option. To avoid paying Article Processing Charges (APCs), you must select the correct option during submission.






Tipüí° Key Terminology




Subscription / Traditional: The reader pays (via university library), so the author pays nothing.
Gold Open Access: The author pays an APC to make the article free for everyone.
Hybrid: A journal that offers BOTH options. You must strictly choose ‚ÄúSubscription‚Äù to publish for free.




How to Select ‚ÄúNo-Fee‚Äù by Publisher








Publisher
System Name
Action Required for Free Publishing




Elsevier
Editorial Manager
Look for the ‚ÄúPublishing Options‚Äù step after acceptance. Select ‚ÄúSubscription‚Äù (often the default is Open Access, be careful).


Springer
Editorial Manager / SNAPP
During submission, you will be asked about Open Access. Select ‚ÄúNo, I want to publish my article via the traditional subscription model‚Äù.


Wiley
ScholarOne
In the license signing phase (Author Services), choose the ‚ÄúOnlineOpen: No‚Äù or ‚ÄúStandard License‚Äù option.


Taylor & Francis
ScholarOne
After acceptance, select ‚ÄúStandard Article‚Äù (Green OA compliant) instead of ‚ÄúGold Open Access‚Äù.


IEEE
ScholarOne
IEEE often has page charges for long papers (e.g., >10 pages). Standard publication is free within page limits; avoid selecting ‚ÄúOpen Access‚Äù.

title: Journals
text:
üõ°Ô∏è Submission & Safety Tips
Before submitting your manuscript, ensure you verify the journal‚Äôs credibility and understand its metrics.


üìä Understanding Metrics
Journals are ranked by Impact Factor (IF) within their subject categories (e.g., Geography, Environmental Sciences).

Q1 (Top 25%): Highest prestige and visibility. Often hardest to accept.
Q2 (Top 25-50%): Excellent quality, balances visibility with slightly higher acceptance rates.
Q3/Q4: Good entry points for niche topics or early-career research.



üö© Avoiding Predatory Journals
Be cautious of ‚ÄúClone Journals‚Äù that mimic the names of reputable titles.

Verify Indexing: Always check the journal on the official Master Journal List (MJL).
Check ISSN: Ensure the ISSN on the journal website matches the one on MJL.
Red Flags: Avoid journals promising ‚ÄúReview in 3 days‚Äù or ‚ÄúGuaranteed Publication‚Äù.

‚è±Ô∏è How to Estimate Review Speed?
Most publishers now provide metrics on their journal homepages: * Elsevier: Look for ‚ÄúTime to First Decision‚Äù and ‚ÄúReview Time‚Äù on the Journal Insights page. * Springer: Check the ‚ÄúJournal Updates‚Äù or ‚ÄúAbout‚Äù section for speed metrics. * Taylor & Francis: Often displays ‚ÄúSpeed/Acceptance‚Äù metrics in the journal banner.

title: The Future of AI in Remote Sensing
text: How deep learning is changing how we interpret satellite imagery‚Ä¶

title: Welcome To My Academic Blog
text:
Welcome to the Spatial Geography Hub
Welcome to my updated personal website and blog! I am thrilled to share my journey as a geographer and spatial data scientist with a global community of researchers and developers.
This blog will serve as a space for: - Courses: Deep dives into Google Earth Engine, Python, and R for geospatial analysis. - Project Updates: Behind-the-scenes looks at the development of my innovations like geeadvance and deepgee. - Field Notes: Insights from workshops, research conventions, and academic fieldwork.
Since this is a platform for geographers, expect to see a lot of satellite imagery, code snippets, and spatial insights. Whether you are a student just starting with GIS or a professional looking for advanced AI-driven spatial tools, I hope you find this content valuable.
Feel free to leave comments using your GitHub account‚ÄîI look forward to engaging in technical discussions and collaborations!

title: Modern GIS with Python: Beyond the Desktop
text: Python has become the de-facto language for spatial data science‚Ä¶

title: The Dual Soul of Geography: Social Science vs.¬†Spatial Science
text: Geography is often described as the ‚Äúmother of all sciences,‚Äù a discipline that uniquely sits at the intersection of the natural and social worlds. But within this broad field, there exists a dynamic tension‚Äîand a powerful synergy‚Äîbetween two dominant paradigms: Geography as a Social Science and Geography as a Spatial Science.

title: The Dual Soul of Geography: Social Science vs.¬†Spatial Science
text:
üß† The Social Science Perspective: Understanding ‚ÄúPlace‚Äù
In the realm of social science, geography is deeply human. It is concerned with the ‚ÄúWhy‚Äù and ‚ÄúHow‚Äù of human existence in specific locations.



The Social Lens: Understanding Human Culture



Focus: Lived experience, culture, politics, and social structures.
Key Concept: ‚ÄúPlace‚Äù ‚Äî a location imbued with meaning, memory, and social relationships.
Methods: Qualitative approaches such as ethnography, interviews, participatory observation, and critical theory.


‚ÄúGeography is not just about where things are, but about what they mean to the people who are there.‚Äù

Social geographers ask questions like: How does gentrification affect community identity? or What are the lived experiences of migration?

title: The Dual Soul of Geography: Social Science vs.¬†Spatial Science
text:
üõ∞Ô∏è The Spatial Science Perspective: Analyzing ‚ÄúSpace‚Äù
On the other side of the spectrum lies spatial science, often driven by the ‚ÄúQuantitative Revolution‚Äù of the mid-20th century. Here, geography becomes a rigorous, measurable science.



The Spatial Perspective: Data and Analysis



Focus: Patterns, distributions, flows, and measurable phenomena.
Key Concept: ‚ÄúSpace‚Äù ‚Äî an abstract, geometric surface where variables interact.
Methods: Geographic Information Systems (GIS), Remote Sensing, spatial statistics, and geocomputation.


‚ÄúEverything is related to everything else, but near things are more related than distant things.‚Äù ‚Äî Waldo Tobler (First Law of Geography)

Spatial scientists ask: What is the optimal location for a new hospital? or How can we model the spread of a wildfire using satellite data?

title: The Dual Soul of Geography: Social Science vs.¬†Spatial Science
section: ü§ù The Convergence: Why We Need Both
text:
ü§ù The Convergence: Why We Need Both
For a long time, these two camps were seen as opposing forces‚Äîthe ‚Äúquants‚Äù vs.¬†the ‚Äúquals.‚Äù However, modern geography increasingly recognizes that this binary is false.



Synthesis and Convergence in Geography



GIS needs Context: A map of poverty rates (Spatial Science) is just data points without understanding the historical and political causes of that poverty (Social Science).
Social Theory needs Grounding: abstract theories about inequality are more powerful when backed by rigorous spatial evidence.


The Rise of ‚ÄúCritical GIS‚Äù and ‚ÄúGeo-Humanities‚Äù
Today, we see a blending of these worlds. Critical GIS scholars use spatial tools to challenge social injustices, while Geo-Humanities researchers use maps to tell rich, human stories.

title: The Dual Soul of Geography: Social Science vs.¬†Spatial Science
text:
Conclusion
Whether you identify more as a social theorist or a spatial analyst, the strength of geography lies in its ability to synthesize. By combining the empathy of social science with the precision of spatial science, we gain a holistic understanding of our complex world.



Bridging the Disciplines


Geography isn‚Äôt just one or the other‚Äîit is the bridge between them.

title: Modern Geospatial Workflow using Python: ML, DL, and AI Integration
text:
The geospatial landscape is undergoing a monumental shift. What once required specialized, heavy desktop software is now being executed with lines of elegant Python code. The integration of Machine Learning (ML), Deep Learning (DL), and Artificial Intelligence (AI) has transformed GIS from a mapping tool into a predictive and analytical powerhouse.
In this post, we explore the architecture of a modern geospatial workflow and why Python is at the heart of this revolution.

title: Modern Geospatial Workflow using Python: ML, DL, and AI Integration
text:
üß± The Foundation: Python‚Äôs Geospatial Stack
Before we dive into AI, we must acknowledge the libraries that make Python a GIS titan. The ‚ÄúGeospatial Stack‚Äù allows us to treat spatial data as first-class citizens in the data science world.

GeoPandas: Brings the power of pandas to vector data, allowing for complex spatial joins and geometric operations in seconds.
Xarray & Rasterio: The dynamic duo for raster data. rasterio handles the I/O of GeoTIFFs, while xarray provides a multi-dimensional platform for analyzing time-series satellite imagery (Data Cubes).
Shapely & PyProj: The engines under the hood for geometric manipulation and coordinate reference system (CRS) transformations.

title: Modern Geospatial Workflow using Python: ML, DL, and AI Integration
text:
ü§ñ The Rise of Machine Learning (ML)
Traditional classification methods like Maximum Likelihood are being replaced by robust ML algorithms. Using Scikit-Learn, geographers can now implement:

Random Forests & SVM: For high-accuracy land cover classification.
Clustering (K-Means): For identifying socio-economic patterns or environmental zones without prior labeling.
Regression Models: To predict environmental variables like Soil Organic Carbon or Urban Heat Island intensity.

The beauty of Python is that your spatial data (from GeoPandas) can be fed directly into these models with minimal translation.

title: Modern Geospatial Workflow using Python: ML, DL, and AI Integration
section: üß† Scaling Up: Deep Learning (DL) for Computer Vision
text:
üß† Scaling Up: Deep Learning (DL) for Computer Vision
Where ML looks at pixel values, Deep Learning looks at patterns, textures, and context. With frameworks like PyTorch and TensorFlow, we are now performing:

Semantic Segmentation: Identifying every single building or tree in high-resolution aerial imagery (e.g., using U-Net architectures).
Object Detection: Automatically counting ships in harbors or identifying solar panels on rooftops.
Change Detection: Using Siamese networks to detect subtle changes in urban sprawl or deforestation between two points in time.

Integrating DL into a geospatial workflow typically involves using libraries like torch-geo or bridging Google Earth Engine with AI models via Earth Engine‚Äôs AI Platform integration.

title: Modern Geospatial Workflow using Python: ML, DL, and AI Integration
section: ‚úçÔ∏è The AI Revolution: LLMs in Geospatial Research
text:
‚úçÔ∏è The AI Revolution: LLMs in Geospatial Research
The most recent addition to our toolkit is the Large Language Model (LLM). AI is not just analyzing the pixels; it is helping us write the code to do so.

Automated Coding: Tools like the GEE AI Assistant (a Chrome extension I developed) leverage Gemini AI to help researchers generate complex scripts in seconds.
Natural Language Queries: We are moving toward a future where you can ask, ‚ÄúFind all areas in Odisha that experienced more than 50% vegetation loss after the 2024 cyclone,‚Äù and the AI generates the processing pipeline.
Research Synthesis: AI helps in summarizing vast amounts of remote sensing literature, identifying gaps, and even formatting citations for academic journals.

title: Modern Geospatial Workflow using Python: ML, DL, and AI Integration
section: ÔøΩÔ∏è The Roadmap: Mastering Python for AI-Driven Research
text:
ÔøΩÔ∏è The Roadmap: Mastering Python for AI-Driven Research
To transition from traditional GIS to AI-driven research, I recommend following this structured 7-step roadmap. This is the core curriculum I follow in my workflows:


1. Python & Statistics

Core Libraries: NumPy, Pandas
Concepts: Probability, OOPs in Python, Statistics for Data Science



2. Intro to Neural Networks (NN)

Architecture: Input Layer, Hidden Layer, Weights, Bias
Logic: Activation Functions, The Perceptron Model, Multi-Layer (ANN)



3. Preprocessing & Artificial Neural Networks (ANN)

Mechanics: Forward Propagation, Backward propagation, Loss functions
Optimization: Adam Optimizer, Multi-Layer Perceptrons



4. Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs)

Geospatial Power: Convolutional Nets for imagery
Frameworks: Keras, Pooling layers for spatial reduction



5. Transfer Learning

Pre-trained Models: VGG16, AlexNet, ResNet
Ecosystems: Hugging Face, Timm (PyTorch Image Models)



6. Object Detection

SOTA Models: YOLO (v8), RCNN, SSD
Segmentation: Mask R-CNN for individual feature extraction



7. Deployment & Serving

From Code to App: Docker containers, Streamlit dashboards
Serving: Scaling Python scripts for production environments

title: Modern Geospatial Workflow using Python: ML, DL, and AI Integration
text:
ÔøΩüöÄ Conclusion: The Hybrid Future
A modern geospatial workflow is no longer about choosing one tool. It is about orchestration.
We use Google Earth Engine for massive data preprocessing, Python for specialized ML/DL modeling, and AI to streamline the entire process. This ‚ÄúModern Workflow‚Äù isn‚Äôt just faster‚Äîit‚Äôs more reproducible, more scalable, and significantly more powerful than anything we‚Äôve seen before.
The era of the ‚ÄúGeospatial Data Scientist‚Äù has arrived. Are you ready?
